572. Homersham Elizabeth Rose (Mrs. Thomas George)
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: Elizabeth Rose Hornsby

2. Your address: R.R. 1, Zehner, Saskatchewan

3. Date: April 12, 1952

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): City of London, England

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: John Wilson, Hotel Manager

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): August 1896

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: London, England until coming to Saskatchewan.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): I was twenty-two years of age

9. What were your reasons for coming West?: To get married, arrived in Regina at 9:00 A.M. and was married at St. Paul's Church, Regina at 11:00 A.M. by Rev. Brown who was rector of St. Paul's at that time.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): My husband preceded me to Canada; he came in 1890, naturally I heard from him and other friends in Canada.
1. Your full name: Elizabeth Rose Thomas

2. Your address: R.R. 1, Zehner

3. Date: April 12, 1896

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): City of London, England

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: John Thomas

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): August 1896

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.: London, England until coming to Saskatchewan.

8. Are children in your family? If so, how many? If not, why not?

9. What were your reasons for coming West? To get married, arrived in Regina at 9:00 A.M. and saw arrival at St. Paul's Church Regina at 11:00 A.M. by Rev. Brown who was pastor of St. Paul's at that time.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Mail order or government information?)

11. Grey County and surrounding areas to Edmonton, he came in 1890; naturally I heard from him and other friends in Canada.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Quite agreeable.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   By myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   The Canadian Pacific Railway to Regina, then horse and buggy from Regina. For a while after that it was oxen and stoneboat.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   The Canadian Pacific Railway to Quebec, C.P.R. to Regina.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   Came straight home to the homestead.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   What is now in the Colonwold District, formerly known as

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   Now

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   In London I worked making Army and Navy Sword knots, Hat Tassels, Sashes etc. - Mrs. Granville.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Quite agreeable.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family)? Friends or strangers?

By myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

The Canadian Pacific Railway (C.P.R.) and the Canadian Northern Railway (C.N.R.).

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Arrived in Edmonton.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Came straight home to the homestead.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

What is now the Edmonton District, formerly homesteaded.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

None.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

How I earned my living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

At Taranto, Alberta, etc. - Alfred Homersham

Homersham, Elizabeth Rose (Mrs. Thomas George)
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

About once a month

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

My husband who died a year ago was Thomas George Homestead.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

My sister came to Saskatchewan from London in 1904 and was married to a friend—George Wilson.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My sister settled on a farm three miles away, she now resides in Regina.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to record?

The Rev. John Harrison now of Three Rivers, Quebec used to conduct church services.

I spent my first Christmas in Canada with Sea Captain Henry Wilson and family.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Steamboat and open covered at first, then the open were replaced by horses, a wagon and later a buggy replaced the wagon.

There were several eventful community fishing trips to the Qu'Appelle valley.

No one had much money, but all got along very nicely. Brillage was the favorite card game; often lasting until it was daylight wondering people might see us go home.
3.

17. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date.

My husband, who died early years ago was Thomas George.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, what was their name?

My sisters came to Saskatchewan from Ontario.

My aunt settled on a farm near Bowden.

Now resides in Regina.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. In there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

The Rev. John Hammond moved there from Prince Albert and to conduct churches arrived.

I spent my first Christmas in Canada with Mr. Captain Johnny Wilson and family.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

At times we traveled by horse, wagon and later a buggy replaced the wagons.

There were several annual events such as fishing trips to the Qu'Appelle valley.

No one had much money, but all got along very nicely.

Children were the favorite card game, often lasting until it was daylight Monday morning.

And so goes home.
25. When was the first car used in the community? About 1907 - Mr. Gibson of Balgonie, he worked on the Bulyea - Balgonie Railroad.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   Not until 1926 - a model T Ford.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Balgonie - twenty miles, Regina - thirty miles after 1910.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Since the use of the motor car and better roads most of our trading is done in Regina.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Monthly about once a month on the average, more often when there was a good deal.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   Hard to answer, some do and others do not go regularly on Saturdays.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   From about 1905 to about 1930 stores used to be a large order go to T. Eaton Co., Winnipeg once or twice a year, at later years more buying is done in Regina and local stores.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   1916 - Balgonie Rural Telephone Company.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   I came here with the idea of making this my permanent home.
24. Was the first car used in the county? About 1907 - Ford Model T.

25. If so, what was the make?

34. Then did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

35. I am now with the idea of making this my permanent home.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Quite a few people moved hoping to better their living. Others stayed and on the whole all remained at the same level.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Not many moved.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Husband was on the Minneatha School Board for several years. My two sons have been members of school boards for several years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given (5) date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

The district used to be known as Hedneyford named after Hedneyford in Staffordshire England where the family of Beldon came from. Hedneyford was also our local P.O. Minneatha School and Church - named from an Indian word meaning "A Beautiful Place."
35. Did any people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "flirtatious" to have or do something in the district, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible. (Such as using the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge etc.)

38. For did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, military stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place name; (2) date and meaning of the name; (3) any changes in names since the first place was given; (4) date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

The district used to be known as Homestead until after the flood of 1910.

Homestead is a beautiful place.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe)

Some old photographs

Would you or the person who owns them either:

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

(Indicate your preference, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Mary Elizabeth Waterwood Johnson (R.R.1), Hughie Gordon, Ethel

Audice Waterwood (Regina), Beatrice (Mrs. Lawrence), Virginia

Thomas Farmer, Surveyor, Saskatchewan

Thomas Farmer, Belle (Lad, Teacher), Churchill

John King, Regina, (Wife, Teacher), Regina, Regina, Regina

Florence High, Female student, Marion, Vancouver, British Columbia

John Johnson, Bachelor at home

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Schools, churches, telephones, machinery, new fruit machines was a new development which cost $9.00 over two years payments, plants, new fruit house cost $5.00
